awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Biochemical Basis of Cellular Circadian Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Paragraph 

By establishing the genetic basis of rhythmic behavior, circadian clock research is a great success story in neuroscience. The molecular clock consists of positive and negative components that form a feedback loop that underlies brain rhythms. However, "the whole is greater than the sum of its parts," and we do not yet know how a handful of components coordinate to give rise to emergent daily rhythms. Therefore, this research aims to identify the biochemical properties of core clock proteins that enable rhythmic behavior. To do this, the team has developed an integrative approach that combines cell-based genetics and continuous monitoring of circadian behavior with biochemical/biophysical methods. This approach will allow them to study the function of clock proteins not only in test tubes in isolation, but also in the context of oscillatory behavior in interacting cells. This work will reveal how the "gears and springs" of the clock interact and function together, and this knowledge will increase our understanding of how the brain keeps time, as well as how proteins interact to regulate complex brain functions. The PI and his colleagues will teach a lecture/lab course that uses a "from math to genes to behavior" platform and provides cross-disciplinary training for graduate students. The team will also teach real world concepts in the local community about the health implications of circadian rhythms, which relates to people of all backgrounds and ages. These broader impacts will strengthen the nation's scientific infrastructure and improve people's health awareness. 

Technical Paragraph 

Genetic studies have identified several core clock components that form a negative feedback mechanism, which underlies circadian behavior. It is well established that, in the core feedback loop, BMAL1 and CLOCK are the two transcription activators and CRY serves as the chief repressor. However, negative feedback in transcription does not necessarily warrant recurring cellular processes with a ~24 hr periodicity. The circadian rhythm is an emergent property enabled by the core clock factors, but the biochemical basis of cellular circadian oscillation is not well understood. Recent studies from this research team show that the structurally flexible C-termini of BMAL1 and CLOCK play essential roles in regulating dynamic interactions with other clock factors to enable circadian oscillations. In the proposed research, the team will employ an integrated approach that combines cell-based genetics and kinetic bioluminescence assays with biochemical and biophysical methods to study how their C-termini use dynamic interactions to regulate rhythm amplitude and period length. In this way, protein function is assessed both in vitro and in the context of cellular circadian behavior. By providing a biochemical basis of cellular circadian behavior, this research will define the molecular architecture of the circadian transcription complex, advance current understanding of the negative feedback mechanism, and further the goals of behavioral neurobiology. During the research, the PI and his colleagues will provide cross-disciplinary education and training for graduate students and inform the general public about the important health implications of circadian rhythms.

por.por_cntn:
Our sleep/wake cycle is regulated by a molecular clock that exists in every cell in the body. The circadian clock in mammals is based on a transcriptional negative feedback loop, consisting of activators (BMAL1, CLOCK) and repressors (CRY1, CRY2). While the genetic basic of circadian behavior is well established, there is a limited understanding of how the core clock proteins are evolved that enable circadian oscillations. The proposed study aims to elucidate the biochemical basis of this mechanism. More specifically, they focus on how the structurally flexible C-terminal regulatory domains (CRDs) of BMAL1 and CLOCK coordinate with each other and with core clock factors such as CRY1 to enable circadian oscillations. In their prior research, also funded by NSF, the PI?s group established the circadian role of the BMAL1 CRD and characterized how the H domain of the CRD mediates dynamic interactions with CRY1 and coactivator CBP. In this funding cycle, they showed that two distinct conformational states within the H domain function to control period length. Mutations of the G helical motif of the BMAL1 CRD affect circadian rhythms. Together with the H helix, these helices represent the only structured regions within the BMAL1 CRD that form a hub for dynamic protein interactions. They also identified a small region within the CLOCK CRD that accounts for its oscillatory function. These studies highlight the role of protein dynamics in regulating circadian oscillations and offer insights into molecular evolution and biochemical basis of circadian behavior, i.e., how the bHLH-PAS core domains of BMAL1 and CLOCK are rendered a new function through elaboration of their C-termini. Further, they discovered that NF-kB interacts with the BMAL1 H domain to impact clock function, thus linking inflammation to clock function. As inflammation underlies many pathological conditions, this finding has important implications in sleep disorders in many diseases and chronic conditions. These studies resulted in two original research articles, two review articles, and at least two new manuscripts under preparation.

The PI has been actively engaged in teaching, training, mentoring, and outreach activities. The PI has i) taught courses to undergraduate students, graduate students, and health professional, ii) trained and mentored graduate and undergraduates, and iii) offered health education and awareness to the general public about the importance of circadian rhythms. He participated in an undergraduate research course ?Science for Life? at the Center for Precollegiate Education and Training to educate and inspire first year undergrads who have aspirations to becoming scientists. During the funding cycle, the PI has mentored three graduate students (one graduated with a PhD and two passed their qualifying exam and became PhD candidates) and trained seven undergraduates (four of which are in graduate or medical schools), as well as several other researchers (postdocs, technicians). The training is in the areas of molecular biology and circadian research, including real-time bioluminescence technology, wheel-running locomotor behavior, and sleep/wake tests. The PI served as a faculty lead of mentoring and advising groups for Graduate Research & Professional Development. Further, the PI gave many talks to the scientific community as well as lay audiences, including high school students, seniors and retirees, and health professionals. He discussed the importance of circadian rhythms in healthy aging and the adverse effects of light at night and unhealthy and mistimed diet on circadian rhythms and sleep. He contributed to his scientific society by serving in committees and as a co-organizer and instructor and served as a co-organizer for the University of Florida Circadian Symposium. Further, patients with Smith-Kingsmore syndrome (SKS) (mostly children) have neurodevelopmental issues and sleep/wake disturbances. The PI is member of the Medical and Scientific Advisory Committee of the SKS Foundation and is actively involved in the SKS community.
